p.stage: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
I learn in this letter that Don Peter of Arragon
comes this night to Messina.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p:
He is very near by this: he was not three leagues off
when I left him.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: How many gentlemen have you lost in this action?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: But few of any sort, and none of name.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
A victory is twice itself when the achiever brings
home full numbers. I find here that Don Peter hath
bestowed much honour on a young Florentine called Claudio.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p:
Much deserved on his part and equally remembered by
Don Pedro: he hath borne himself beyond the
promise of his age, doing, in the figure of a lamb,
the feats of a lion: he hath indeed better
bettered expectation than you must expect of me to
tell you how.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
He hath an uncle here in Messina will be very much
glad of it.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p:
I have already delivered him letters, and there
appears much joy in him; even so much that joy could
not show itself modest enough without a badge of
bitterness.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: Did he break out into tears?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: In great measure.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
A kind overflow of kindness: there are no faces
truer than those that are so washed. How much
better is it to weep at joy than to joy at weeping!

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
I pray you, is Signior Mountanto returned from the
wars or no?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p:
I know none of that name, lady: there was none such
in the army of any sort.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: What is he that you ask for, niece?

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: O, he's returned; and as pleasant as ever he was.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
He set up his bills here in Messina and challenged
Cupid at the flight; and my uncle's fool, reading
the challenge, subscribed for Cupid, and challenged
him at the bird-bolt. I pray you, how many hath he
killed and eaten in these wars? But how many hath
he killed? for indeed I promised to eat all of his killing.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
Faith, niece, you tax Signior Benedick too much;
but he'll be meet with you, I doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: He hath done good service, lady, in these wars.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
You had musty victual, and he hath holp to eat it:
he is a very valiant trencherman; he hath an
excellent stomach.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: And a good soldier too, lady.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: And a good soldier to a lady: but what is he to a lord?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p:
A lord to a lord, a man to a man; stuffed with all
honourable virtues.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
It is so, indeed; he is no less than a stuffed man:
but for the stuffing,—well, we are all mortal.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
You must not, sir, mistake my niece. There is a
kind of merry war betwixt Signior Benedick and her:
they never meet but there's a skirmish of wit
between them.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Alas! he gets nothing by that. In our last
conflict four of his five wits went halting off, and
now is the whole man governed with one: so that if
he have wit enough to keep himself warm, let him
bear it for a difference between himself and his
horse; for it is all the wealth that he hath left,
to be known a reasonable creature. Who is his
companion now? He hath every month a new sworn brother.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Very easily possible: he wears his faith but as
the fashion of his hat; it ever changes with the
next block.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: I see, lady, the gentleman is not in your books.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
No; an he were, I would burn my study. But, I pray
you, who is his companion? Is there no young
squarer now that will make a voyage with him to the devil?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
O Lord, he will hang upon him like a disease: he
is sooner caught than the pestilence, and the taker
runs presently mad. God help the noble Claudio! if
he have caught the Benedick, it will cost him a
thousand pound ere a' be cured.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: I will hold friends with you, lady.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: Do, good friend.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: You will never run mad, niece.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: No, not till a hot January.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Don Pedro is approached.

p.stage: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Good Signior Leonato, you are come to meet your
trouble: the fashion of the world is to avoid
cost, and you encounter it.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
Never came trouble to my house in the likeness of
your grace: for trouble being gone, comfort should
remain; but when you depart from me, sorrow abides
and happiness takes his leave.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
You embrace your charge too willingly. I think this
is your daughter.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: Her mother hath many times told me so.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Were you in doubt, sir, that you asked her?

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: Signior Benedick, no; for then were you a child.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
You have it full, Benedick: we may guess by this
what you are, being a man. Truly, the lady fathers
herself. Be happy, lady; for you are like an
honourable father.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
If Signior Leonato be her father, she would not
have his head on her shoulders for all Messina, as
like him as she is.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
I wonder that you will still be talking, Signior
Benedick: nobody marks you.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: What, my dear Lady Disdain! are you yet living?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Is it possible disdain should die while she hath
such meet food to feed it as Signior Benedick?
Courtesy itself must convert to disdain, if you come
in her presence.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Then is courtesy a turncoat. But it is certain I
am loved of all ladies, only you excepted: and I
would I could find in my heart that I had not a hard
heart; for, truly, I love none.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
A dear happiness to women: they would else have
been troubled with a pernicious suitor. I thank God
and my cold blood, I am of your humour for that: I
had rather hear my dog bark at a crow than a man
swear he loves me.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
God keep your ladyship still in that mind! so some
gentleman or other shall 'scape a predestinate
scratched face.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Scratching could not make it worse, an 'twere such
a face as yours were.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Well, you are a rare parrot-teacher.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: A bird of my tongue is better than a beast of yours.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
I would my horse had the speed of your tongue, and
so good a continuer. But keep your way, i' God's
name; I have done.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: You always end with a jade's trick: I know you of old.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
That is the sum of all, Leonato. Signior Claudio
and Signior Benedick, my dear friend Leonato hath
invited you all. I tell him we shall stay here at
the least a month; and he heartily prays some
occasion may detain us longer. I dare swear he is no
hypocrite, but prays from his heart.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: If you swear, my lord, you shall not be forsworn.

Let me bid you welcome, my lord: being reconciled to
the prince your brother, I owe you all duty.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
I thank you: I am not of many words, but I thank
you.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: Please it your grace lead on?

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Your hand, Leonato; we will go together.

p.stage: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Benedick, didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: I noted her not; but I looked on her.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Is she not a modest young lady?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Do you question me, as an honest man should do, for
my simple true judgment; or would you have me speak
after my custom, as being a professed tyrant to their sex?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: No; I pray thee speak in sober judgment.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Why, i' faith, methinks she's too low for a high
praise, too brown for a fair praise and too little
for a great praise: only this commendation I can
afford her, that were she other than she is, she
were unhandsome; and being no other but as she is, I
do not like her.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
Thou thinkest I am in sport: I pray thee tell me
truly how thou likest her.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Would you buy her, that you inquire after her?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Can the world buy such a jewel?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Yea, and a case to put it into. But speak you this
with a sad brow? or do you play the flouting Jack,
to tell us Cupid is a good hare-finder and Vulcan a
rare carpenter? Come, in what key shall a man take
you, to go in the song?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
In mine eye she is the sweetest lady that ever I
looked on.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
I can see yet without spectacles and I see no such
matter: there's her cousin, an she were not
possessed with a fury, exceeds her as much in beauty
as the first of May doth the last of December. But I
hope you have no intent to turn husband, have you?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
I would scarce trust myself, though I had sworn the
contrary, if Hero would be my wife.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Is't come to this? In faith, hath not the world
one man but he will wear his cap with suspicion?
Shall I never see a bachelor of three-score again?
Go to, i' faith; an thou wilt needs thrust thy neck
into a yoke, wear the print of it and sigh away
Sundays. Look Don Pedro is returned to seek you.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
What secret hath held you here, that you followed
not to Leonato's?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: I would your grace would constrain me to tell.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: I charge thee on thy allegiance.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
You hear, Count Claudio: I can be secret as a dumb
man; I would have you think so; but, on my
allegiance, mark you this, on my allegiance. He is
in love. With who? now that is your grace's part.
Mark how short his answer is;—With Hero, Leonato's
short daughter.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: If this were so, so were it uttered.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Like the old tale, my lord: 'it is not so, nor
'twas not so, but, indeed, God forbid it should be
so.'

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
If my passion change not shortly, God forbid it
should be otherwise.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Amen, if you love her; for the lady is very well worthy.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: You speak this to fetch me in, my lord.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: By my troth, I speak my thought.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: And, in faith, my lord, I spoke mine.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: And, by my two faiths and troths, my lord, I spoke mine.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: That I love her, I feel.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: That she is worthy, I know.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
That I neither feel how she should be loved nor
know how she should be worthy, is the opinion that
fire cannot melt out of me: I will die in it at the stake.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Thou wast ever an obstinate heretic in the despite
of beauty.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
And never could maintain his part but in the force
of his will.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
That a woman conceived me, I thank her; that she
brought me up, I likewise give her most humble
thanks: but that I will have a recheat winded in my
forehead, or hang my bugle in an invisible baldrick,
all women shall pardon me. Because I will not do
them the wrong to mistrust any, I will do myself the
right to trust none; and the fine is, for the which
I may go the finer, I will live a bachelor.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: I shall see thee, ere I die, look pale with love.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
With anger, with sickness, or with hunger, my lord,
not with love: prove that ever I lose more blood
with love than I will get again with drinking, pick
out mine eyes with a ballad-maker's pen and hang me
up at the door of a brothel-house for the sign of
blind Cupid.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Well, if ever thou dost fall from this faith, thou
wilt prove a notable argument.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
If I do, hang me in a bottle like a cat and shoot
at me; and he that hits me, let him be clapped on
the shoulder, and called Adam.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Well, as time shall try: 'In time the savage bull
doth bear the yoke.'

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
The savage bull may; but if ever the sensible
Benedick bear it, pluck off the bull's horns and set
them in my forehead: and let me be vilely painted,
and in such great letters as they write 'Here is
good horse to hire,' let them signify under my sign
'Here you may see Benedick the married man.'

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: If this should ever happen, thou wouldst be horn-mad.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Nay, if Cupid have not spent all his quiver in
Venice, thou wilt quake for this shortly.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: I look for an earthquake too, then.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Well, you temporize with the hours. In the
meantime, good Signior Benedick, repair to
Leonato's: commend me to him and tell him I will
not fail him at supper; for indeed he hath made
great preparation.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
I have almost matter enough in me for such an
embassage; and so I commit you—

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: To the tuition of God: From my house, if I had it,—

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: The sixth of July: Your loving friend, Benedick.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Nay, mock not, mock not. The body of your
discourse is sometime guarded with fragments, and
the guards are but slightly basted on neither: ere
you flout old ends any further, examine your
conscience: and so I leave you.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: My liege, your highness now may do me good.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
My love is thine to teach: teach it but how,
And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn
Any hard lesson that may do thee good.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Hath Leonato any son, my lord?

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
No child but Hero; she's his only heir.
Dost thou affect her, Claudio?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
O, my lord,
When you went onward on this ended action,
I look'd upon her with a soldier's eye,
That liked, but had a rougher task in hand
Than to drive liking to the name of love:
But now I am return'd and that war-thoughts
Have left their places vacant, in their rooms
Come thronging soft and delicate desires,
All prompting me how fair young Hero is,
Saying, I liked her ere I went to wars.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Thou wilt be like a lover presently
And tire the hearer with a book of words.
If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it,
And I will break with her and with her father,
And thou shalt have her. Was't not to this end
That thou began'st to twist so fine a story?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
How sweetly you do minister to love,
That know love's grief by his complexion!
But lest my liking might too sudden seem,
I would have salved it with a longer treatise.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
What need the bridge much broader than the flood?
The fairest grant is the necessity.
Look, what will serve is fit: 'tis once, thou lovest,
And I will fit thee with the remedy.
I know we shall have revelling to-night:
I will assume thy part in some disguise
And tell fair Hero I am Claudio,
And in her bosom I'll unclasp my heart
And take her hearing prisoner with the force
And strong encounter of my amorous tale:
Then after to her father will I break;
And the conclusion is, she shall be thine.
In practise let us put it presently.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
How now, brother! Where is my cousin, your son?
hath he provided this music?

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p:
He is very busy about it. But, brother, I can tell
you strange news that you yet dreamt not of.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: Are they good?

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p:
As the event stamps them: but they have a good
cover; they show well outward. The prince and Count
Claudio, walking in a thick-pleached alley in mine
orchard, were thus much overheard by a man of mine:
the prince discovered to Claudio that he loved my
niece your daughter and meant to acknowledge it
this night in a dance: and if he found her
accordant, he meant to take the present time by the
top and instantly break with you of it.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: Hath the fellow any wit that told you this?

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p:
A good sharp fellow: I will send for him; and
question him yourself.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
No, no; we will hold it as a dream till it appear
itself: but I will acquaint my daughter withal,
that she may be the better prepared for an answer,
if peradventure this be true. Go you and tell her of it.

Cousins, you know what you have to do. O, I cry you
mercy, friend; go you with me, and I will use your
skill. Good cousin, have a care this busy time.

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p:
What the good-year, my lord! why are you thus out
of measure sad?

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
There is no measure in the occasion that breeds;
therefore the sadness is without limit.

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p: You should hear reason.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p: And when I have heard it, what blessing brings it?

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p:
If not a present remedy, at least a patient
sufferance.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
I wonder that thou, being, as thou sayest thou art,
born under Saturn, goest about to apply a moral
medicine to a mortifying mischief. I cannot hide
what I am: I must be sad when I have cause and smile
at no man's jests, eat when I have stomach and wait
for no man's leisure, sleep when I am drowsy and
tend on no man's business, laugh when I am merry and
claw no man in his humour.

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p:
Yea, but you must not make the full show of this
till you may do it without controlment. You have of
late stood out against your brother, and he hath
ta'en you newly into his grace; where it is
impossible you should take true root but by the
fair weather that you make yourself: it is needful
that you frame the season for your own harvest.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
I had rather be a canker in a hedge than a rose in
his grace, and it better fits my blood to be
disdained of all than to fashion a carriage to rob
love from any: in this, though I cannot be said to
be a flattering honest man, it must not be denied
but I am a plain-dealing villain. I am trusted with
a muzzle and enfranchised with a clog; therefore I
have decreed not to sing in my cage. If I had my
mouth, I would bite; if I had my liberty, I would do
my liking: in the meantime let me be that I am and
seek not to alter me.

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p: Can you make no use of your discontent?

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
I make all use of it, for I use it only.
Who comes here?
What news, Borachio?

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
I came yonder from a great supper: the prince your
brother is royally entertained by Leonato: and I
can give you intelligence of an intended marriage.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
Will it serve for any model to build mischief on?
What is he for a fool that betroths himself to
unquietness?

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p: Marry, it is your brother's right hand.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p: Who? the most exquisite Claudio?

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p: Even he.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
A proper squire! And who, and who? which way looks
he?

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p: Marry, on Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p: A very forward March-chick! How came you to this?

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
Being entertained for a perfumer, as I was smoking a
musty room, comes me the prince and Claudio, hand
in hand in sad conference: I whipt me behind the
arras; and there heard it agreed upon that the
prince should woo Hero for himself, and having
obtained her, give her to Count Claudio.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
Come, come, let us thither: this may prove food to
my displeasure. That young start-up hath all the
glory of my overthrow: if I can cross him any way, I
bless myself every way. You are both sure, and will assist me?

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p: To the death, my lord.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
Let us to the great supper: their cheer is the
greater that I am subdued. Would the cook were of
my mind! Shall we go prove what's to be done?

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p: We'll wait upon your lordship.

p.stage: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: Was not Count John here at supper?

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: I saw him not.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
How tartly that gentleman looks! I never can see
him but I am heart-burned an hour after.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: He is of a very melancholy disposition.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
He were an excellent man that were made just in the
midway between him and Benedick: the one is too
like an image and says nothing, and the other too
like my lady's eldest son, evermore tattling.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
Then half Signior Benedick's tongue in Count John's
mouth, and half Count John's melancholy in Signior
Benedick's face,—

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
With a good leg and a good foot, uncle, and money
enough in his purse, such a man would win any woman
in the world, if a' could get her good-will.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
By my troth, niece, thou wilt never get thee a
husband, if thou be so shrewd of thy tongue.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: In faith, she's too curst.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Too curst is more than curst: I shall lessen God's
sending that way; for it is said, 'God sends a curst
cow short horns;' but to a cow too curst he sends none.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: So, by being too curst, God will send you no horns.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Just, if he send me no husband; for the which
blessing I am at him upon my knees every morning and
evening. Lord, I could not endure a husband with a
beard on his face: I had rather lie in the woollen.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: You may light on a husband that hath no beard.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
What should I do with him? dress him in my apparel
and make him my waiting-gentlewoman? He that hath a
beard is more than a youth, and he that hath no
beard is less than a man: and he that is more than
a youth is not for me, and he that is less than a
man, I am not for him: therefore, I will even take
sixpence in earnest of the bear-ward, and lead his
apes into hell.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: Well, then, go you into hell?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
No, but to the gate; and there will the devil meet
me, like an old cuckold, with horns on his head, and
say 'Get you to heaven, Beatrice, get you to
heaven; here's no place for you maids:' so deliver
I up my apes, and away to Saint Peter for the
heavens; he shows me where the bachelors sit, and
there live we as merry as the day is long.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p:
[To HERO] Well, niece, I trust you will be ruled
by your father.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Yes, faith; it is my cousin's duty to make curtsy
and say 'Father, as it please you.' But yet for all
that, cousin, let him be a handsome fellow, or else
make another curtsy and say 'Father, as it please
me.'

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: Well, niece, I hope to see you one day fitted with a husband.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Not till God make men of some other metal than
earth. Would it not grieve a woman to be
overmastered with a pierce of valiant dust? to make
an account of her life to a clod of wayward marl?
No, uncle, I'll none: Adam's sons are my brethren;
and, truly, I hold it a sin to match in my kindred.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
Daughter, remember what I told you: if the prince
do solicit you in that kind, you know your answer.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
The fault will be in the music, cousin, if you be
not wooed in good time: if the prince be too
important, tell him there is measure in every thing
and so dance out the answer. For, hear me, Hero:
wooing, wedding, and repenting, is as a Scotch jig,
a measure, and a cinque pace: the first suit is hot
and hasty, like a Scotch jig, and full as
fantastical; the wedding, mannerly-modest, as a
measure, full of state and ancientry; and then comes
repentance and, with his bad legs, falls into the
cinque pace faster and faster, till he sink into his grave.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: Cousin, you apprehend passing shrewdly.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: I have a good eye, uncle; I can see a church by daylight.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: The revellers are entering, brother: make good room.

p.stage: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO, MARGARET, URSULA and others, masked

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Lady, will you walk about with your friend?

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
So you walk softly and look sweetly and say nothing,
I am yours for the walk; and especially when I walk away.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: With me in your company?

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: I may say so, when I please.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: And when please you to say so?

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
When I like your favour; for God defend the lute
should be like the case!

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: My visor is Philemon's roof; within the house is Jove.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: Why, then, your visor should be thatched.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Speak low, if you speak love.

sp.speaker: BALTHASAR
sp.p: Well, I would you did like me.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
So would not I, for your own sake; for I have many
ill-qualities.

sp.speaker: BALTHASAR
sp.p: Which is one?

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p: I say my prayers aloud.

sp.speaker: BALTHASAR
sp.p: I love you the better: the hearers may cry, Amen.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p: God match me with a good dancer!

sp.speaker: BALTHASAR
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
And God keep him out of my sight when the dance is
done! Answer, clerk.

sp.speaker: BALTHASAR
sp.p: No more words: the clerk is answered.

sp.speaker: URSULA
sp.p: I know you well enough; you are Signior Antonio.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: At a word, I am not.

sp.speaker: URSULA
sp.p: I know you by the waggling of your head.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: To tell you true, I counterfeit him.

sp.speaker: URSULA
sp.p:
You could never do him so ill-well, unless you were
the very man. Here's his dry hand up and down: you
are he, you are he.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: At a word, I am not.

sp.speaker: URSULA
sp.p:
Come, come, do you think I do not know you by your
excellent wit? can virtue hide itself? Go to,
mum, you are he: graces will appear, and there's an
end.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: Will you not tell me who told you so?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: No, you shall pardon me.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: Nor will you not tell me who you are?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Not now.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
That I was disdainful, and that I had my good wit
out of the 'Hundred Merry Tales:'—well this was
Signior Benedick that said so.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: What's he?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: I am sure you know him well enough.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Not I, believe me.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: Did he never make you laugh?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: I pray you, what is he?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Why, he is the prince's jester: a very dull fool;
only his gift is in devising impossible slanders:
none but libertines delight in him; and the
commendation is not in his wit, but in his villany;
for he both pleases men and angers them, and then
they laugh at him and beat him. I am sure he is in
the fleet: I would he had boarded me.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: When I know the gentleman, I'll tell him what you say.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Do, do: he'll but break a comparison or two on me;
which, peradventure not marked or not laughed at,
strikes him into melancholy; and then there's a
partridge wing saved, for the fool will eat no
supper that night.
We must follow the leaders.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: In every good thing.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will leave them at
the next turning.

p.stage: Dance. Then exeunt all except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, and CLAUDIO

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
Sure my brother is amorous on Hero and hath
withdrawn her father to break with him about it.
The ladies follow her and but one visor remains.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p: And that is Claudio: I know him by his bearing.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p: Are not you Signior Benedick?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: You know me well; I am he.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
Signior, you are very near my brother in his love:
he is enamoured on Hero; I pray you, dissuade him
from her: she is no equal for his birth: you may
do the part of an honest man in it.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: How know you he loves her?

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p: I heard him swear his affection.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p: So did I too; and he swore he would marry her to-night.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p: Come, let us to the banquet.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
Thus answer I in the name of Benedick,
But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio.
'Tis certain so; the prince wooes for himself.
Friendship is constant in all other things
Save in the office and affairs of love:
Therefore, all hearts in love use their own tongues;
Let every eye negotiate for itself
And trust no agent; for beauty is a witch
Against whose charms faith melteth into blood.
This is an accident of hourly proof,
Which I mistrusted not. Farewell, therefore, Hero!

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Count Claudio?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Yea, the same.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Come, will you go with me?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Even to the next willow, about your own business,
county. What fashion will you wear the garland of?
about your neck, like an usurer's chain? or under
your arm, like a lieutenant's scarf? You must wear
it one way, for the prince hath got your Hero.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: I wish him joy of her.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Why, that's spoken like an honest drovier: so they
sell bullocks. But did you think the prince would
have served you thus?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: I pray you, leave me.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Ho! now you strike like the blind man: 'twas the
boy that stole your meat, and you'll beat the post.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: If it will not be, I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Alas, poor hurt fowl! now will he creep into sedges.
But that my Lady Beatrice should know me, and not
know me! The prince's fool! Ha? It may be I go
under that title because I am merry. Yea, but so I
am apt to do myself wrong; I am not so reputed: it
is the base, though bitter, disposition of Beatrice
that puts the world into her person and so gives me
out. Well, I'll be revenged as I may.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Now, signior, where's the count? did you see him?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Troth, my lord, I have played the part of Lady Fame.
I found him here as melancholy as a lodge in a
warren: I told him, and I think I told him true,
that your grace had got the good will of this young
lady; and I offered him my company to a willow-tree,
either to make him a garland, as being forsaken, or
to bind him up a rod, as being worthy to be whipped.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: To be whipped! What's his fault?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
The flat transgression of a schoolboy, who, being
overjoyed with finding a birds' nest, shows it his
companion, and he steals it.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Wilt thou make a trust a transgression? The
transgression is in the stealer.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Yet it had not been amiss the rod had been made,
and the garland too; for the garland he might have
worn himself, and the rod he might have bestowed on
you, who, as I take it, have stolen his birds' nest.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
I will but teach them to sing, and restore them to
the owner.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
If their singing answer your saying, by my faith,
you say honestly.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you: the
gentleman that danced with her told her she is much
wronged by you.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
O, she misused me past the endurance of a block!
an oak but with one green leaf on it would have
answered her; my very visor began to assume life and
scold with her. She told me, not thinking I had been
myself, that I was the prince's jester, that I was
duller than a great thaw; huddling jest upon jest
with such impossible conveyance upon me that I stood
like a man at a mark, with a whole army shooting at
me. She speaks poniards, and every word stabs:
if her breath were as terrible as her terminations,
there were no living near her; she would infect to
the north star. I would not marry her, though she
were endowed with all that Adam bad left him before
he transgressed: she would have made Hercules have
turned spit, yea, and have cleft his club to make
the fire too. Come, talk not of her: you shall find
her the infernal Ate in good apparel. I would to God
some scholar would conjure her; for certainly, while
she is here, a man may live as quiet in hell as in a
sanctuary; and people sin upon purpose, because they
would go thither; so, indeed, all disquiet, horror
and perturbation follows her.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Look, here she comes.

p.stage: Enter CLAUDIO, BEATRICE, HERO, and LEONATO

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Will your grace command me any service to the
world's end? I will go on the slightest errand now
to the Antipodes that you can devise to send me on;
I will fetch you a tooth-picker now from the
furthest inch of Asia, bring you the length of
Prester John's foot, fetch you a hair off the great
Cham's beard, do you any embassage to the Pigmies,
rather than hold three words' conference with this
harpy. You have no employment for me?

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: None, but to desire your good company.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
O God, sir, here's a dish I love not: I cannot
endure my Lady Tongue.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Come, lady, come; you have lost the heart of
Signior Benedick.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Indeed, my lord, he lent it me awhile; and I gave
him use for it, a double heart for his single one:
marry, once before he won it of me with false dice,
therefore your grace may well say I have lost it.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: You have put him down, lady, you have put him down.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
So I would not he should do me, my lord, lest I
should prove the mother of fools. I have brought
Count Claudio, whom you sent me to seek.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Why, how now, count! wherefore are you sad?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Not sad, my lord.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: How then? sick?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Neither, my lord.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
The count is neither sad, nor sick, nor merry, nor
well; but civil count, civil as an orange, and
something of that jealous complexion.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
I' faith, lady, I think your blazon to be true;
though, I'll be sworn, if he be so, his conceit is
false. Here, Claudio, I have wooed in thy name, and
fair Hero is won: I have broke with her father,
and his good will obtained: name the day of
marriage, and God give thee joy!

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
Count, take of me my daughter, and with her my
fortunes: his grace hath made the match, and an
grace say Amen to it.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: Speak, count, 'tis your cue.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
Silence is the perfectest herald of joy: I were
but little happy, if I could say how much. Lady, as
you are mine, I am yours: I give away myself for
you and dote upon the exchange.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Speak, cousin; or, if you cannot, stop his mouth
with a kiss, and let not him speak neither.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: In faith, lady, you have a merry heart.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Yea, my lord; I thank it, poor fool, it keeps on
the windy side of care. My cousin tells him in his
ear that he is in her heart.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: And so she doth, cousin.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Good Lord, for alliance! Thus goes every one to the
world but I, and I am sunburnt; I may sit in a
corner and cry heigh-ho for a husband!

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
I would rather have one of your father's getting.
Hath your grace ne'er a brother like you? Your
father got excellent husbands, if a maid could come by them.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Will you have me, lady?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
No, my lord, unless I might have another for
working-days: your grace is too costly to wear
every day. But, I beseech your grace, pardon me: I
was born to speak all mirth and no matter.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Your silence most offends me, and to be merry best
becomes you; for, out of question, you were born in
a merry hour.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
No, sure, my lord, my mother cried; but then there
was a star danced, and under that was I born.
Cousins, God give you joy!

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: Niece, will you look to those things I told you of?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: I cry you mercy, uncle. By your grace's pardon.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: By my troth, a pleasant-spirited lady.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
There's little of the melancholy element in her, my
lord: she is never sad but when she sleeps, and
not ever sad then; for I have heard my daughter say,
she hath often dreamed of unhappiness and waked
herself with laughing.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: She cannot endure to hear tell of a husband.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: O, by no means: she mocks all her wooers out of suit.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: She were an excellent wife for Benedict.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
O Lord, my lord, if they were but a week married,
they would talk themselves mad.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: County Claudio, when mean you to go to church?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
To-morrow, my lord: time goes on crutches till love
have all his rites.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
Not till Monday, my dear son, which is hence a just
seven-night; and a time too brief, too, to have all
things answer my mind.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Come, you shake the head at so long a breathing:
but, I warrant thee, Claudio, the time shall not go
dully by us. I will in the interim undertake one of
Hercules' labours; which is, to bring Signior
Benedick and the Lady Beatrice into a mountain of
affection the one with the other. I would fain have
it a match, and I doubt not but to fashion it, if
you three will but minister such assistance as I
shall give you direction.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
My lord, I am for you, though it cost me ten
nights' watchings.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: And I, my lord.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: And you too, gentle Hero?

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
I will do any modest office, my lord, to help my
cousin to a good husband.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
And Benedick is not the unhopefullest husband that
I know. Thus far can I praise him; he is of a noble
strain, of approved valour and confirmed honesty. I
will teach you how to humour your cousin, that she
shall fall in love with Benedick; and I, with your
two helps, will so practise on Benedick that, in
despite of his quick wit and his queasy stomach, he
shall fall in love with Beatrice. If we can do this,
Cupid is no longer an archer: his glory shall be
ours, for we are the only love-gods. Go in with me,
and I will tell you my drift.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
It is so; the Count Claudio shall marry the
daughter of Leonato.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p: Yea, my lord; but I can cross it.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
Any bar, any cross, any impediment will be
medicinable to me: I am sick in displeasure to him,
and whatsoever comes athwart his affection ranges
evenly with mine. How canst thou cross this marriage?

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
Not honestly, my lord; but so covertly that no
dishonesty shall appear in me.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p: Show me briefly how.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
I think I told your lordship a year since, how much
I am in the favour of Margaret, the waiting
gentlewoman to Hero.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p: I remember.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
I can, at any unseasonable instant of the night,
appoint her to look out at her lady's chamber window.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p: What life is in that, to be the death of this marriage?

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
The poison of that lies in you to temper. Go you to
the prince your brother; spare not to tell him that
he hath wronged his honour in marrying the renowned
Claudio—whose estimation do you mightily hold
up—to a contaminated stale, such a one as Hero.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p: What proof shall I make of that?

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
Proof enough to misuse the prince, to vex Claudio,
to undo Hero and kill Leonato. Look you for any
other issue?

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p: Only to despite them, I will endeavour any thing.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
Go, then; find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and
the Count Claudio alone: tell them that you know
that Hero loves me; intend a kind of zeal both to the
prince and Claudio, as,—in love of your brother's
honour, who hath made this match, and his friend's
reputation, who is thus like to be cozened with the
semblance of a maid,—that you have discovered
thus. They will scarcely believe this without trial:
offer them instances; which shall bear no less
likelihood than to see me at her chamber-window,
hear me call Margaret Hero, hear Margaret term me
Claudio; and bring them to see this the very night
before the intended wedding,—for in the meantime I
will so fashion the matter that Hero shall be
absent,—and there shall appear such seeming truth
of Hero's disloyalty that jealousy shall be called
assurance and all the preparation overthrown.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
Grow this to what adverse issue it can, I will put
it in practise. Be cunning in the working this, and
thy fee is a thousand ducats.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
Be you constant in the accusation, and my cunning
shall not shame me.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p: I will presently go learn their day of marriage.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Boy!

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Signior?

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
In my chamber-window lies a book: bring it hither
to me in the orchard.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I am here already, sir.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: I know that; but I would have thee hence, and here again.

I do much wonder that one man, seeing how much
another man is a fool when he dedicates his
behaviors to love, will, after he hath laughed at
such shallow follies in others, become the argument
of his own scorn by failing in love: and such a man
is Claudio. I have known when there was no music
with him but the drum and the fife; and now had he
rather hear the tabour and the pipe: I have known
when he would have walked ten mile a-foot to see a
good armour; and now will he lie ten nights awake,
carving the fashion of a new doublet. He was wont to
speak plain and to the purpose, like an honest man
and a soldier; and now is he turned orthography; his
words are a very fantastical banquet, just so many
strange dishes. May I be so converted and see with
these eyes? I cannot tell; I think not: I will not
be sworn, but love may transform me to an oyster; but
I'll take my oath on it, till he have made an oyster
of me, he shall never make me such a fool. One woman
is fair, yet I am well; another is wise, yet I am
well; another virtuous, yet I am well; but till all
graces be in one woman, one woman shall not come in
my grace. Rich she shall be, that's certain; wise,
or I'll none; virtuous, or I'll never cheapen her;
fair, or I'll never look on her; mild, or come not
near me; noble, or not I for an angel; of good
discourse, an excellent musician, and her hair shall
be of what colour it please God. Ha! the prince and
Monsieur Love! I will hide me in the arbour.

p.stage: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and LEONATO

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Come, shall we hear this music?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
Yea, my good lord. How still the evening is,
As hush'd on purpose to grace harmony!

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: See you where Benedick hath hid himself?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
O, very well, my lord: the music ended,
We'll fit the kid-fox with a pennyworth.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Come, Balthasar, we'll hear that song again.

sp.speaker: BALTHASAR
sp.p:
O, good my lord, tax not so bad a voice
To slander music any more than once.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
It is the witness still of excellency
To put a strange face on his own perfection.
I pray thee, sing, and let me woo no more.

sp.speaker: BALTHASAR
sp.p:
Because you talk of wooing, I will sing;
Since many a wooer doth commence his suit
To her he thinks not worthy, yet he wooes,
Yet will he swear he loves.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
BALTHASAR
sp.p:
Note this before my notes;
There's not a note of mine that's worth the noting.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Why, these are very crotchets that he speaks;
Note, notes, forsooth, and nothing.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Now, divine air! now is his soul ravished! Is it
not strange that sheeps' guts should hale souls out
of men's bodies? Well, a horn for my money, when
all's done.

sp.speaker: BALTHASAR
sp.p:
Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more,
Men were deceivers ever,
One foot in sea and one on shore,
To one thing constant never:
Then sigh not so, but let them go,
And be you blithe and bonny,
Converting all your sounds of woe
Into Hey nonny, nonny.
Sing no more ditties, sing no moe,
Of dumps so dull and heavy;
The fraud of men was ever so,
Since summer first was leafy:
Then sigh not so, &c.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: By my troth, a good song.

sp.speaker: BALTHASAR
sp.p: And an ill singer, my lord.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Ha, no, no, faith; thou singest well enough for a shift.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
An he had been a dog that should have howled thus,
they would have hanged him: and I pray God his bad
voice bode no mischief. I had as lief have heard the
night-raven, come what plague could have come after
it.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Yea, marry, dost thou hear, Balthasar? I pray thee,
get us some excellent music; for to-morrow night we
would have it at the Lady Hero's chamber-window.

sp.speaker: BALTHASAR
sp.p: The best I can, my lord.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Do so: farewell.

Come hither, Leonato. What was it you told me of
to-day, that your niece Beatrice was in love with
Signior Benedick?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
O, ay: stalk on. stalk on; the fowl sits. I did
never think that lady would have loved any man.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
No, nor I neither; but most wonderful that she
should so dote on Signior Benedick, whom she hath in
all outward behaviors seemed ever to abhor.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Is't possible? Sits the wind in that corner?

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
By my troth, my lord, I cannot tell what to think
of it but that she loves him with an enraged
affection: it is past the infinite of thought.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: May be she doth but counterfeit.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Faith, like enough.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
O God, counterfeit! There was never counterfeit of
passion came so near the life of passion as she
discovers it.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Why, what effects of passion shows she?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Bait the hook well; this fish will bite.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
What effects, my lord? She will sit you, you heard
my daughter tell you how.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: She did, indeed.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
How, how, pray you? You amaze me: I would have I
thought her spirit had been invincible against all
assaults of affection.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
I would have sworn it had, my lord; especially
against Benedick.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
I should think this a gull, but that the
white-bearded fellow speaks it: knavery cannot,
sure, hide himself in such reverence.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: He hath ta'en the infection: hold it up.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Hath she made her affection known to Benedick?

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: No; and swears she never will: that's her torment.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
'Tis true, indeed; so your daughter says: 'Shall
I,' says she, 'that have so oft encountered him
with scorn, write to him that I love him?'

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
This says she now when she is beginning to write to
him; for she'll be up twenty times a night, and
there will she sit in her smock till she have writ a
sheet of paper: my daughter tells us all.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a
pretty jest your daughter told us of.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
O, when she had writ it and was reading it over, she
found Benedick and Beatrice between the sheet?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: That.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
O, she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence;
railed at herself, that she should be so immodest
to write to one that she knew would flout her; 'I
measure him,' says she, 'by my own spirit; for I
should flout him, if he writ to me; yea, though I
love him, I should.'

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
Then down upon her knees she falls, weeps, sobs,
beats her heart, tears her hair, prays, curses; 'O
sweet Benedick! God give me patience!'

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
She doth indeed; my daughter says so: and the
ecstasy hath so much overborne her that my daughter
is sometime afeared she will do a desperate outrage
to herself: it is very true.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
It were good that Benedick knew of it by some
other, if she will not discover it.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
To what end? He would make but a sport of it and
torment the poor lady worse.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
An he should, it were an alms to hang him. She's an
excellent sweet lady; and, out of all suspicion,
she is virtuous.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: And she is exceeding wise.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: In every thing but in loving Benedick.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
O, my lord, wisdom and blood combating in so tender
a body, we have ten proofs to one that blood hath
the victory. I am sorry for her, as I have just
cause, being her uncle and her guardian.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
I would she had bestowed this dotage on me: I would
have daffed all other respects and made her half
myself. I pray you, tell Benedick of it, and hear
what a' will say.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: Were it good, think you?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
Hero thinks surely she will die; for she says she
will die, if he love her not, and she will die, ere
she make her love known, and she will die, if he woo
her, rather than she will bate one breath of her
accustomed crossness.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
She doth well: if she should make tender of her
love, 'tis very possible he'll scorn it; for the
man, as you know all, hath a contemptible spirit.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: He is a very proper man.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: He hath indeed a good outward happiness.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Before God! and, in my mind, very wise.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: He doth indeed show some sparks that are like wit.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: And I take him to be valiant.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
As Hector, I assure you: and in the managing of
quarrels you may say he is wise; for either he
avoids them with great discretion, or undertakes
them with a most Christian-like fear.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
If he do fear God, a' must necessarily keep peace:
if he break the peace, he ought to enter into a
quarrel with fear and trembling.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
And so will he do; for the man doth fear God,
howsoever it seems not in him by some large jests
he will make. Well I am sorry for your niece. Shall
we go seek Benedick, and tell him of her love?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
Never tell him, my lord: let her wear it out with
good counsel.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: Nay, that's impossible: she may wear her heart out first.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Well, we will hear further of it by your daughter:
let it cool the while. I love Benedick well; and I
could wish he would modestly examine himself, to see
how much he is unworthy so good a lady.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: My lord, will you walk? dinner is ready.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
If he do not dote on her upon this, I will never
trust my expectation.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Let there be the same net spread for her; and that
must your daughter and her gentlewomen carry. The
sport will be, when they hold one an opinion of
another's dotage, and no such matter: that's the
scene that I would see, which will be merely a
dumb-show. Let us send her to call him in to dinner.

p.stage: Exeunt DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and LEONATO

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
[Coming forward] This can be no trick: the
conference was sadly borne. They have the truth of
this from Hero. They seem to pity the lady: it
seems her affections have their full bent. Love me!
why, it must be requited. I hear how I am censured:
they say I will bear myself proudly, if I perceive
the love come from her; they say too that she will
rather die than give any sign of affection. I did
never think to marry: I must not seem proud: happy
are they that hear their detractions and can put
them to mending. They say the lady is fair; 'tis a
truth, I can bear them witness; and virtuous; 'tis
so, I cannot reprove it; and wise, but for loving
me; by my troth, it is no addition to her wit, nor
no great argument of her folly, for I will be
horribly in love with her. I may chance have some
odd quirks and remnants of wit broken on me,
because I have railed so long against marriage: but
doth not the appetite alter? a man loves the meat
in his youth that he cannot endure in his age.
Shall quips and sentences and these paper bullets of
the brain awe a man from the career of his humour?
No, the world must be peopled. When I said I would
die a bachelor, I did not think I should live till I
were married. Here comes Beatrice. By this day!
she's a fair lady: I do spy some marks of love in
her.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to dinner.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
I took no more pains for those thanks than you take
pains to thank me: if it had been painful, I would
not have come.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: You take pleasure then in the message?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Yea, just so much as you may take upon a knife's
point and choke a daw withal. You have no stomach,
signior: fare you well.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Ha! 'Against my will I am sent to bid you come in
to dinner;' there's a double meaning in that 'I took
no more pains for those thanks than you took pains
to thank me.' that's as much as to say, Any pains
that I take for you is as easy as thanks. If I do
not take pity of her, I am a villain; if I do not
love her, I am a Jew. I will go get her picture.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
Good Margaret, run thee to the parlor;
There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice
Proposing with the prince and Claudio:
Whisper her ear and tell her, I and Ursula
Walk in the orchard and our whole discourse
Is all of her; say that thou overheard'st us;
And bid her steal into the pleached bower,
Where honeysuckles, ripen'd by the sun,
Forbid the sun to enter, like favourites,
Made proud by princes, that advance their pride
Against that power that bred it: there will she hide her,
To listen our purpose. This is thy office;
Bear thee well in it and leave us alone.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p: I'll make her come, I warrant you, presently.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come,
As we do trace this alley up and down,
Our talk must only be of Benedick.
When I do name him, let it be thy part
To praise him more than ever man did merit:
My talk to thee must be how Benedick
Is sick in love with Beatrice. Of this matter
Is little Cupid's crafty arrow made,
That only wounds by hearsay.

sp.speaker: URSULA
sp.p:
The pleasant'st angling is to see the fish
Cut with her golden oars the silver stream,
And greedily devour the treacherous bait:
So angle we for Beatrice; who even now
Is couched in the woodbine coverture.
Fear you not my part of the dialogue.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
Then go we near her, that her ear lose nothing
Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it.

sp.speaker: URSULA
sp.p:
But are you sure
That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: So says the prince and my new-trothed lord.

sp.speaker: URSULA
sp.p: And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
They did entreat me to acquaint her of it;
But I persuaded them, if they loved Benedick,
To wish him wrestle with affection,
And never to let Beatrice know of it.

sp.speaker: URSULA
sp.p:
Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman
Deserve as full as fortunate a bed
As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
O god of love! I know he doth deserve
As much as may be yielded to a man:
But Nature never framed a woman's heart
Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice;
Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes,
Misprising what they look on, and her wit
Values itself so highly that to her
All matter else seems weak: she cannot love,
Nor take no shape nor project of affection,
She is so self-endeared.

sp.speaker: URSULA
HERO
URSULA
sp.p: Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
No, not to be so odd and from all fashions
As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable:
But who dare tell her so? If I should speak,
She would mock me into air; O, she would laugh me
Out of myself, press me to death with wit.
Therefore let Benedick, like cover'd fire,
Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly:
It were a better death than die with mocks,
Which is as bad as die with tickling.

sp.speaker: URSULA
sp.p: Yet tell her of it: hear what she will say.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
No; rather I will go to Benedick
And counsel him to fight against his passion.
And, truly, I'll devise some honest slanders
To stain my cousin with: one doth not know
How much an ill word may empoison liking.

sp.speaker: URSULA
sp.p:
O, do not do your cousin such a wrong.
She cannot be so much without true judgment—
Having so swift and excellent a wit
As she is prized to have—as to refuse
So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
He is the only man of Italy.
Always excepted my dear Claudio.

sp.speaker: URSULA
sp.p:
I pray you, be not angry with me, madam,
Speaking my fancy: Signior Benedick,
For shape, for bearing, argument and valour,
Goes foremost in report through Italy.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: Indeed, he hath an excellent good name.

sp.speaker: URSULA
sp.p:
His excellence did earn it, ere he had it.
When are you married, madam?

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
Why, every day, to-morrow. Come, go in:
I'll show thee some attires, and have thy counsel
Which is the best to furnish me to-morrow.

sp.speaker: URSULA
sp.p: She's limed, I warrant you: we have caught her, madam.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
If it proves so, then loving goes by haps:
Some Cupid kills with arrows, some with traps.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
[Coming forward]
What fire is in mine ears? Can this be true?
Stand I condemn'd for pride and scorn so much?
Contempt, farewell! and maiden pride, adieu!
No glory lives behind the back of such.
And, Benedick, love on; I will requite thee,
Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand:
If thou dost love, my kindness shall incite thee
To bind our loves up in a holy band;
For others say thou dost deserve, and I
Believe it better than reportingly.

p.stage: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and
then go I toward Arragon.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
I'll bring you thither, my lord, if you'll
vouchsafe me.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss
of your marriage as to show a child his new coat
and forbid him to wear it. I will only be bold
with Benedick for his company; for, from the crown
of his head to the sole of his foot, he is all
mirth: he hath twice or thrice cut Cupid's
bow-string and the little hangman dare not shoot at
him; he hath a heart as sound as a bell and his
tongue is the clapper, for what his heart thinks his
tongue speaks.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Gallants, I am not as I have been.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p:
So say I
methinks you are sadder.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: I hope he be in love.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Hang him, truant! there's no true drop of blood in
him, to be truly touched with love: if he be sad,
he wants money.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: I have the toothache.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Draw it.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p: Hang it!

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: You must hang it first, and draw it afterwards.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: What! sigh for the toothache?

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: Where is but a humour or a worm.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Well, every one can master a grief but he that has
it.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Yet say I, he is in love.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
There is no appearance of fancy in him, unless it be
a fancy that he hath to strange disguises; as, to be
a Dutchman today, a Frenchman to-morrow, or in the
shape of two countries at once, as, a German from
the waist downward, all slops, and a Spaniard from
the hip upward, no doublet. Unless he have a fancy
to this foolery, as it appears he hath, he is no
fool for fancy, as you would have it appear he is.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
If he be not in love with some woman, there is no
believing old signs: a' brushes his hat o'
mornings; what should that bode?

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Hath any man seen him at the barber's?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
No, but the barber's man hath been seen with him,
and the old ornament of his cheek hath already
stuffed tennis-balls.

sp.speaker: LEONATO
sp.p: Indeed, he looks younger than he did, by the loss of a beard.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Nay, a' rubs himself with civet: can you smell him
out by that?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: That's as much as to say, the sweet youth's in love.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: The greatest note of it is his melancholy.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: And when was he wont to wash his face?

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Yea, or to paint himself? for the which, I hear
what they say of him.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
Nay, but his jesting spirit; which is now crept into
a lute-string and now governed by stops.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
Indeed, that tells a heavy tale for him: conclude,
conclude he is in love.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Nay, but I know who loves him.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: That would I know too: I warrant, one that knows him not.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
Yes, and his ill conditions; and, in despite of
all, dies for him.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: She shall be buried with her face upwards.

sp.speaker: BENEDICK
sp.p:
Yet is this no charm for the toothache. Old
signior, walk aside with me: I have studied eight
or nine wise words to speak to you, which these
hobby-horses must not hear.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: For my life, to break with him about Beatrice.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
'Tis even so. Hero and Margaret have by this
played their parts with Beatrice; and then the two
bears will not bite one another when they meet.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p: My lord and brother, God save you!

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Good den, brother.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p: If your leisure served, I would speak with you.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: In private?

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
If it please you: yet Count Claudio may hear; for
what I would speak of concerns him.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
[To CLAUDIO] Means your lordship to be married
to-morrow?

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: You know he does.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p: I know not that, when he knows what I know.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
You may think I love you not: let that appear
hereafter, and aim better at me by that I now will
manifest. For my brother, I think he holds you
well, and in dearness of heart hath holp to effect
your ensuing marriage;—surely suit ill spent and
labour ill bestowed.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
I came hither to tell you; and, circumstances
shortened, for she has been too long a talking of,
the lady is disloyal.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Who, Hero?

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: Even she; Leonato's Hero, your Hero, every man's Hero:

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: Disloyal?

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
The word is too good to paint out her wickedness; I
could say she were worse: think you of a worse
title, and I will fit her to it. Wonder not till
further warrant: go but with me to-night, you shall
see her chamber-window entered, even the night
before her wedding-day: if you love her then,
to-morrow wed her; but it would better fit your honour
to change your mind.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: May this be so?

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: I will not think it.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
If you dare not trust that you see, confess not
that you know: if you will follow me, I will show
you enough; and when you have seen more and heard
more, proceed accordingly.

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p:
If I see any thing to-night why I should not marry
her to-morrow in the congregation, where I should
wed, there will I shame her.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p:
And, as I wooed for thee to obtain her, I will join
with thee to disgrace her.

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
I will disparage her no farther till you are my
witnesses: bear it coldly but till midnight, and
let the issue show itself.

sp.speaker: DON PEDRO
sp.p: O day untowardly turned!

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.p: O mischief strangely thwarting!

sp.speaker: DON JOHN
sp.p:
O plague right well prevented! so will you say when
you have seen the sequel.

p.stage: Enter DOGBERRY and VERGES with the Watch

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p: Are you good men and true?

sp.speaker: VERGES
sp.p:
Yea, or else it were pity but they should suffer
salvation, body and soul.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Nay, that were a punishment too good for them, if
they should have any allegiance in them, being
chosen for the prince's watch.

sp.speaker: VERGES
sp.p: Well, give them their charge, neighbour Dogberry.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
First, who think you the most desertless man to be
constable?

sp.speaker: First Watchman
sp.p:
Hugh Otecake, sir, or George Seacole; for they can
write and read.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Come hither, neighbour Seacole. God hath blessed
you with a good name: to be a well-favoured man is
the gift of fortune; but to write and read comes by nature.

sp.speaker: Second Watchman
sp.p: Both which, master constable,—

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
You have: I knew it would be your answer. Well,
for your favour, sir, why, give God thanks, and make
no boast of it; and for your writing and reading,
let that appear when there is no need of such
vanity. You are thought here to be the most
senseless and fit man for the constable of the
watch; therefore bear you the lantern. This is your
charge: you shall comprehend all vagrom men; you are
to bid any man stand, in the prince's name.

sp.speaker: Second Watchman
sp.p: How if a' will not stand?

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Why, then, take no note of him, but let him go; and
presently call the rest of the watch together and
thank God you are rid of a knave.

sp.speaker: VERGES
sp.p:
If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none
of the prince's subjects.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
True, and they are to meddle with none but the
prince's subjects. You shall also make no noise in
the streets; for, for the watch to babble and to
talk is most tolerable and not to be endured.

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.p:
We will rather sleep than talk: we know what
belongs to a watch.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Why, you speak like an ancient and most quiet
watchman; for I cannot see how sleeping should
offend: only, have a care that your bills be not
stolen. Well, you are to call at all the
ale-houses, and bid those that are drunk get them to bed.

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.p: How if they will not?

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Why, then, let them alone till they are sober: if
they make you not then the better answer, you may
say they are not the men you took them for.

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.p: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
If you meet a thief, you may suspect him, by virtue
of your office, to be no true man; and, for such
kind of men, the less you meddle or make with them,
why the more is for your honesty.

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.p:
If we know him to be a thief, shall we not lay
hands on him?

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Truly, by your office, you may; but I think they
that touch pitch will be defiled: the most peaceable
way for you, if you do take a thief, is to let him
show himself what he is and steal out of your company.

sp.speaker: VERGES
sp.p: You have been always called a merciful man, partner.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Truly, I would not hang a dog by my will, much more
a man who hath any honesty in him.

sp.speaker: VERGES
sp.p:
If you hear a child cry in the night, you must call
to the nurse and bid her still it.

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.p: How if the nurse be asleep and will not hear us?

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Why, then, depart in peace, and let the child wake
her with crying; for the ewe that will not hear her
lamb when it baes will never answer a calf when he bleats.

sp.speaker: VERGES
sp.p: 'Tis very true.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
This is the end of the charge:—you, constable, are
to present the prince's own person: if you meet the
prince in the night, you may stay him.

sp.speaker: VERGES
sp.p: Nay, by'r our lady, that I think a' cannot.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Five shillings to one on't, with any man that knows
the statutes, he may stay him: marry, not without
the prince be willing; for, indeed, the watch ought
to offend no man; and it is an offence to stay a
man against his will.

sp.speaker: VERGES
sp.p: By'r lady, I think it be so.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha! Well, masters, good night: an there be
any matter of weight chances, call up me: keep your
fellows' counsels and your own; and good night.
Come, neighbour.

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.p:
Well, masters, we hear our charge: let us go sit here
upon the church-bench till two, and then all to bed.

sp.speaker: DOGBERRY
sp.p:
One word more, honest neighbours. I pray you watch
about Signior Leonato's door; for the wedding being
there to-morrow, there is a great coil to-night.
Adieu: be vigitant, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p: What Conrade!

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.p: [Aside] Peace! stir not.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p: Conrade, I say!

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p: Here, man; I am at thy elbow.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
Mass, and my elbow itched; I thought there would a
scab follow.

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p:
I will owe thee an answer for that: and now forward
with thy tale.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
Stand thee close, then, under this pent-house, for
it drizzles rain; and I will, like a true drunkard,
utter all to thee.

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.p: [Aside] Some treason, masters: yet stand close.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p: Therefore know I have earned of Don John a thousand ducats.

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p: Is it possible that any villany should be so dear?

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
Thou shouldst rather ask if it were possible any
villany should be so rich; for when rich villains
have need of poor ones, poor ones may make what
price they will.

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p: I wonder at it.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
That shows thou art unconfirmed. Thou knowest that
the fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloak, is
nothing to a man.

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p: Yes, it is apparel.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p: I mean, the fashion.

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p: Yes, the fashion is the fashion.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
Tush! I may as well say the fool's the fool. But
seest thou not what a deformed thief this fashion
is?

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.p:
[Aside] I know that Deformed; a' has been a vile
thief this seven year; a' goes up and down like a
gentleman: I remember his name.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p: Didst thou not hear somebody?

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p: No; 'twas the vane on the house.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
Seest thou not, I say, what a deformed thief this
fashion is? how giddily a' turns about all the hot
bloods between fourteen and five-and-thirty?
sometimes fashioning them like Pharaoh's soldiers
in the reeky painting, sometime like god Bel's
priests in the old church-window, sometime like the
shaven Hercules in the smirched worm-eaten tapestry,
where his codpiece seems as massy as his club?

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p:
All this I see; and I see that the fashion wears
out more apparel than the man. But art not thou
thyself giddy with the fashion too, that thou hast
shifted out of thy tale into telling me of the fashion?

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
Not so, neither: but know that I have to-night
wooed Margaret, the Lady Hero's gentlewoman, by the
name of Hero: she leans me out at her mistress'
chamber-window, bids me a thousand times good
night,—I tell this tale vilely:—I should first
tell thee how the prince, Claudio and my master,
planted and placed and possessed by my master Don
John, saw afar off in the orchard this amiable encounter.

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p: And thought they Margaret was Hero?

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
Two of them did, the prince and Claudio; but the
devil my master knew she was Margaret; and partly
by his oaths, which first possessed them, partly by
the dark night, which did deceive them, but chiefly
by my villany, which did confirm any slander that
Don John had made, away went Claudio enraged; swore
he would meet her, as he was appointed, next morning
at the temple, and there, before the whole
congregation, shame her with what he saw o'er night
and send her home again without a husband.

sp.speaker: First Watchman
sp.p: We charge you, in the prince's name, stand!

sp.speaker: Second Watchman
sp.p:
Call up the right master constable. We have here
recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery that
ever was known in the commonwealth.

sp.speaker: First Watchman
sp.p:
And one Deformed is one of them: I know him; a'
wears a lock.

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p: Masters, masters,—

sp.speaker: Second Watchman
sp.p: You'll be made bring Deformed forth, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p: Masters,—

sp.speaker: First Watchman
sp.p: Never speak: we charge you let us obey you to go with us.

sp.speaker: BORACHIO
sp.p:
We are like to prove a goodly commodity, being taken
up of these men's bills.

sp.speaker: CONRADE
sp.p: A commodity in question, I warrant you. Come, we'll obey you.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice, and desire
her to rise.

sp.speaker: URSULA
sp.p: I will, lady.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: And bid her come hither.

sp.speaker: URSULA
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p: Troth, I think your other rabato were better.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: No, pray thee, good Meg, I'll wear this.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
By my troth, 's not so good; and I warrant your
cousin will say so.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
My cousin's a fool, and thou art another: I'll wear
none but this.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
I like the new tire within excellently, if the hair
were a thought browner; and your gown's a most rare
fashion, i' faith. I saw the Duchess of Milan's
gown that they praise so.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: O, that exceeds, they say.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
By my troth, 's but a night-gown in respect of
yours: cloth o' gold, and cuts, and laced with
silver, set with pearls, down sleeves, side sleeves,
and skirts, round underborne with a bluish tinsel:
but for a fine, quaint, graceful and excellent
fashion, yours is worth ten on 't.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
God give me joy to wear it! for my heart is
exceeding heavy.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p: 'Twill be heavier soon by the weight of a man.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: Fie upon thee! art not ashamed?

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
Of what, lady? of speaking honourably? Is not
marriage honourable in a beggar? Is not your lord
honourable without marriage? I think you would have
me say, 'saving your reverence, a husband:' and bad
thinking do not wrest true speaking, I'll offend
nobody: is there any harm in 'the heavier for a
husband'? None, I think, and it be the right husband
and the right wife; otherwise 'tis light, and not
heavy: ask my Lady Beatrice else; here she comes.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: Good morrow, coz.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: Good morrow, sweet Hero.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: Why how now? do you speak in the sick tune?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: I am out of all other tune, methinks.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
Clap's into 'Light o' love;' that goes without a
burden: do you sing it, and I'll dance it.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Ye light o' love, with your heels! then, if your
husband have stables enough, you'll see he shall
lack no barns.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p: O illegitimate construction! I scorn that with my heels.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
'Tis almost five o'clock, cousin; tis time you were
ready. By my troth, I am exceeding ill: heigh-ho!

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p: For a hawk, a horse, or a husband?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: For the letter that begins them all, H.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
Well, and you be not turned Turk, there's no more
sailing by the star.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: What means the fool, trow?

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p: Nothing I; but God send every one their heart's desire!

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p:
These gloves the count sent me; they are an
excellent perfume.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: I am stuffed, cousin; I cannot smell.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p: A maid, and stuffed! there's goodly catching of cold.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
O, God help me! God help me! how long have you
professed apprehension?

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p: Even since you left it. Doth not my wit become me rarely?

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
It is not seen enough, you should wear it in your
cap. By my troth, I am sick.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
Get you some of this distilled Carduus Benedictus,
and lay it to your heart: it is the only thing for a qualm.

sp.speaker: HERO
sp.p: There thou prickest her with a thistle.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p:
Benedictus! why Benedictus? you have some moral in
this Benedictus.

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p:
Moral! no, by my troth, I have no moral meaning; I
meant, plain holy-thistle. You may think perchance
that I think you are in love: nay, by'r lady, I am
not such a fool to think what I list, nor I list
not to think what I can, nor indeed I cannot think,
if I would think my heart out of thinking, that you
are in love or that you will be in love or that you
can be in love. Yet Benedick was such another, and
now is he become a man: he swore he would never
marry, and yet now, in despite of his heart, he eats
his meat without grudging: and how you may be
converted I know not, but methinks you look with
your eyes as other women do.

sp.speaker: BEATRICE
sp.p: What pace is this that thy tongue keeps?

sp.speaker: MARGARET
sp.p: Not a false gallop.

sp.speaker: URSULA
sp.p:
Madam, withdraw: the prince, the count, Signior
